articles.headline: A Break for Embattled Ranchers
articles.snippet: Japan’s move to ease restrictions on American beef imports will allow ranchers and meatpackers to move past a mad cow scare that led to a ban in 2003, and regain full access to what was once their most lucrative market.
articles.abstract: Japan’s move to ease restrictions on American beef imports will allow ranchers and meatpackers to move past a mad cow scare that led to a ban in 2003, and regain full access to what was once their most lucrative market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reflecting diminishing fears over mad cow disease, Japan eased its decade-old restriction on imports of American beef on Monday, but industry experts said beef producers faced many more challenges to reverse a prolonged slump that has pared the nation’s herd to its lowest level in 60 years and sent prices soaring.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Base for Spy Drones in North Africa
articles.snippet: The military’s Africa Command is making preparations to install unarmed drones as Islamist extremist groups are seen as posing a growing menace to the region.
articles.abstract: The military’s Africa Command is making preparations to install unarmed drones as Islamist extremist groups are seen as posing a growing menace to the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States military is preparing to establish a drone base in northwest Africa so that it can increase surveillance missions on the local affiliate of Al Qaeda and other Islamist extremist groups that American and other Western officials say pose a growing menace to the region.

articles.headline: In the Air, Minor Tiffs Can Escalate Fast
articles.snippet: Flight attendants are trained to avoid escalating conflict, but the “nip it in the bud” approach may seem aggressive to passengers.
articles.abstract: Flight attendants are trained to avoid escalating conflict, but the “nip it in the bud” approach may seem aggressive to passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a time of heightened security concerns, disgruntled airline employees and frustrated passengers can be a combustible combination in a crowded aircraft, as travelers find themselves subject to lots of rules and little wiggle room to challenge them.

articles.headline: In a Quick Shift, Scouts Rethink a Ban on Gays
articles.snippet: Under a new proposed policy, the Boy Scouts of America would allow local scouting groups to choose whether to allow gay members.
articles.abstract: Under a new proposed policy, the Boy Scouts of America would allow local scouting groups to choose whether to allow gay members.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Boy Scouts of America, with its traditions of youth in uniform and the character-building virtues of honor, has always looked back to an older, more structured image of America, when gay and lesbian people were invisible and silent. It was a view reaffirmed in Scout policy as recently as seven months ago. Openly gay scouts and scout leaders need not apply.

articles.headline: The Chief of Yahoo Lifts Sales, and Spirits
articles.snippet: Marissa Mayer’s first months as chief executive have impressed investors, and the company’s stock, recently at a four-year high, rose after hours.
articles.abstract: Marissa Mayer’s first months as chief executive have impressed investors, and the company’s stock, recently at a four-year high, rose after hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, just by being Marissa Mayer, has done more to move Yahoo forward in her first six months as chief executive than any of her five predecessors did over as many years.

articles.headline: Former Jefferies Trader Is Charged With Fraud
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors charged a former trader from the Jefferies Group with defrauding clients and the government while selling them mortgage-backed securities.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors charged a former trader from the Jefferies Group with defrauding clients and the government while selling them mortgage-backed securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors charged a former senior trader at the Jefferies Group on Monday with defrauding his clients — and the government — while selling them mortgage-backed securities after the financial crisis.

articles.headline: For Search, Facebook Had to Go Beyond ‘Robospeak’
articles.snippet: Before Facebook introduced a search tool this month, it assembled a varied team to study what users were searching for and to teach computers how to communicate better with people.
articles.abstract: Before Facebook introduced a search tool this month, it assembled a varied team to study what users were searching for and to teach computers how to communicate better with people.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Human behavior is Facebook’s business.

articles.headline:
Biotech Firms,
Billions at Risk,
Lobby States to
Limit Generics
articles.snippet: The industry’s lobbying effort could blunt new competition to its products and reduce the savings anticipated in the federal health care overhaul.
articles.abstract: The industry’s lobbying effort could blunt new competition to its products and reduce the savings anticipated in the federal health care overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: In statehouses around the country, some of the nation’s biggest biotechnology companies are lobbying intensively to limit generic competition to their blockbuster drugs, potentially cutting into the billions of dollars in savings on drug costs contemplated in the federal health care overhaul law.

articles.headline: Nominee for ‘Sheriff’ Has Worn Banks’ Hat
articles.snippet: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s pick to run the Securities and Exchange Commission, is a former defender of those she’d be expected to oversee.
articles.abstract: Mary Jo White, President Obama’s pick to run the Securities and Exchange Commission, is a former defender of those she’d be expected to oversee.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You don’t want to mess with Mary Jo.”

articles.headline: As Music Streaming Grows, Royalties Slow to a Trickle
articles.snippet: Companies like Spotify and Pandora are catching fire, but the money paid to artists is often tiny, which has the music industry on edge.
articles.abstract: Companies like Spotify and Pandora are catching fire, but the money paid to artists is often tiny, which has the music industry on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like plenty of music fans, Sam Broe jumped at the chance to join Spotify two summers ago, and he hasn’t looked back.

articles.headline: Chaos in Egypt Stirs Warning of a Collapse
articles.snippet: Gen. Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the defense minister, warned of dire consequences if Egypt’s political forces failed to reconcile, reflecting impatience from the country’s most powerful institution.
articles.abstract: Gen. Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the defense minister, warned of dire consequences if Egypt’s political forces failed to reconcile, reflecting impatience from the country’s most powerful institution.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As three Egyptian cities defied President Mohamed Morsi’s attempt to quell the anarchy spreading through their streets, the nation’s top general warned Tuesday that the state itself was in danger of collapse if the feuding civilian leaders could not agree on a solution to restore order.

articles.headline: European Cloud Over Ford
articles.snippet: Ford Motor posted a 54 percent gain in adjusted fourth-quarter profit, despite heavy losses in the troubled European market.
articles.abstract: Ford Motor posted a 54 percent gain in adjusted fourth-quarter profit, despite heavy losses in the troubled European market.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Last year, Ford Motor broke ranks with other auto companies when it announced major cuts in its troubled European operations, including the closing of three factories, to address a sharp downturn in sales on the continent and an oversupply of vehicles.

articles.headline: CNN President Tries to Repeat Success in Morning News
articles.snippet: A new morning show is the first of several building blocks for the struggling cable news channel, led by Jeff Zucker, who revived the “Today” show for NBC.
articles.abstract: A new morning show is the first of several building blocks for the struggling cable news channel, led by Jeff Zucker, who revived the “Today” show for NBC.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, a young producer named Jeff Zucker helped a down-on-its-luck “Today” show regain its ratings mojo and start what became a 16-year winning streak. More recently, he was a sounding board for Ben Sherwood, the president of ABC News, as Mr. Sherwood’s “Good Morning America” finally ended the “Today” show’s streak.
